channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Airstrike in Damascus Kills Several Top Iranian Commanders, Iranian Media Say
item.description: Seven officers, including three generals in Iran’s Quds Force, were reported killed in the attack on a building in Damascus, which both Iran and Israeli officials said was carried out by Israel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A Russian Defector’s Killing Raises Specter of Hit Squads
item.description: The death in Spain of Maksim Kuzminov, a pilot who delivered a helicopter and secret documents to Ukraine, has raised fears that the Kremlin is again targeting its enemies.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and José Bautista
item.media:description: Police officers investigating the parking garage in Villajoyosa, Spain, where the body of a Russian defector, Maksim Kuzminov, was found in February.

item.title: Angry Farmers Are Reshaping Europe
item.description: Farm protests are changing not only Europe’s food system but also its politics, as the far right senses an opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Benoit Merlo’s organic farm in eastern France.

item.title: Turkey’s Opposition Strikes Elections Blow to Erdogan’s Party
item.description: A raft of local election victories by rivals of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s governing party could serve as a check on his power.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Yavuz Ozden/Dia Images, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his wife, Emine Erdogan, at his party headquarters in Ankara, the Turkish capital, early Monday.

item.title: Former Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou to Visit China
item.description: A rare visit to mainland China by Ma Ying-jeou, who’s now in the opposition, is a chance for political messaging on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Ma Ying-jeou, who was Taiwan’s president from 2008 to 2016, favors closer ties with China.

item.title: The Bizarre Chinese Murder Plot Behind Netflix’s ‘3 Body Problem’
item.description: Lin Qi, a billionaire who helped produce the science-fiction hit, was poisoned to death by a disgruntled executive. His attacker now faces the death penalty.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Zhang Zhi/Red Star News/Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Lin Qi spent millions to buy the rights to a Chinese science-fiction novel called “The Three-Body Problem” but was murdered before it launched as a television series.

item.title: American YouTuber Freed After Kidnapping in Haiti
item.description: Adisson Pierre Maalouf, who is from Georgia, was kidnapped two weeks ago by a gang leader after traveling to Haiti.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams and Andre Paultre

item.title: ‘Oppenheimer’ Opens in Japan, Earning $2.5 Million in First Three Days
item.description: While some viewers lamented the movie’s exclusion of scenes from Hiroshima or Nagasaki, others said they recognized that it had another story to tell.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:description: A poster for “Oppenheimer” in Tokyo on Friday. The movie opened in Japan eight months after its release in the United States.

item.title: What Happened When This Italian Province Invested in Babies
item.description: The area around Bolzano has a thick network of family support provided by the government. That means a steady birthrate in a country facing a demographic plunge.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Davide Monteleone for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stefano Baldo shopping at the local supermarket with his sons Ruben and Gioele in Bolzano, Italy, this month. Large families have increasingly become uncommon in Italy, which has one of the lowest birthrates in Europe.

item.title: Centuries of Irish Archives Destroyed in Civil War Are Being Recreated
item.description: A globe-spanning research project has turned the catalog of a public archive destroyed in Ireland’s civil war into a model for reconstruction.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lynn Kilgallon, a research fellow at the Virtual Record Treasury of Ireland, at the Public Record Office of Northern Ireland in Belfast.

item.title: Pope Francis Calls for Gaza Cease-Fire in Easter Message
item.description: Pope Francis’ decisions to reduce his participation in two major Holy Week events had raised fears about his health.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Pope Francis delivered his traditional Easter message on Sunday at the Vatican.

item.title: Water Crisis in India’s Silicon Valley
item.description: Bengaluru gets plenty of rain. But the city did not properly adapt as its soaring population strained traditional water sources.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Atul Loke
item.media:description: Filling up with subsidized water at a government distribution center in the Indian city of Bengaluru, also known as Bangalore.

item.title: In Yemen, Conflict and Hunger Stalk a Lean Ramadan
item.description: Airstrikes, crippling inflation and a drop in foreign aid are raising alarms about a new humanitarian crisis in the world’s poorest Arab country.
item.dc:creator: Saeed Al-Batati and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Children collecting humanitarian aid provided by a Kuwaiti charitable organization this month on the outskirts of Marib, Yemen.

item.title: King Charles III Attends Easter Service After Cancer Diagnosis
item.description: The family has been thrown off balance by health crises, including cancer diagnoses for the king and Catherine, Princess of Wales. She and her husband, Prince William, did not appear.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla greeting people after the Easter service on Sunday at Windsor Castle.

item.title: Netanyahu Faces Growing Pressure From All Sides
item.description: The prime minister is being pulled in opposing directions by his coalition partners, Israeli public opinion and allies abroad, with the war in Gaza and his political future in the balance.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A demonstrator against Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government in Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: Betty Cole Dukert, Top ‘Meet the Press’ Producer, Dies at 96
item.description: She worked as a secretary before being hired as an associate producer at the NBC News public affairs show in 1956. She went on to spend 41 years there.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Outside Israel’s Parliament, Protesters Explain Why Netanyahu Must Go
item.description: A tent camp is a temporary home for some of the thousands of Israelis who are mounting a four-day protest calling for early elections to oust the Israeli prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Tents of protesters camped outside of the Parliament building, the Knesset, in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: Cease-Fire Talks to Confront How Displaced Palestinians Can Return
item.description: Many Palestinians from northern Gaza are now sheltering in the south, but they want to return home.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Displaced Palestinians in Rafah, along the border with Egypt, on Saturday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Protests against Israel’s prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Anti-government protesters on Sunday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Israeli Protests Against Netanyahu Intensify as Cease-Fire Talks Resume
item.description: Thousands have taken to the streets of Israel to demand that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu be replaced.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Vivian Yee and Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: The Israeli police dispersed people protesting exemptions for ultra-Orthodox Jews from mandatory military service in Jerusalem on Sunday.

item.title: Palestinian Christians Mark Easter in Gaza’s Only Catholic Church
item.description: Somber Easter celebrations were held on Sunday for hundreds of displaced Palestinians at the Holy Family Church in Gaza City.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Easter Mass at the Holy Family Church in Gaza City on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Israeli Anger at Netanyahu Grows
item.description: Plus, the new end-of-the-world fiction.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Anti-government protesters yesterday in Jerusalem.

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu Undergoes Hernia Surgery Amid Mounting Pressure
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office said the procedure was a success. Earlier, Mr. Netanyahu responded to criticism that he had not done enough to secure the release of hostages.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Johnatan Reiss
item.media:description: Israel’s justice minister, a member of Netanyahu’s Likud party, will step in for the prime minister while he undergoes surgery.

item.title: Thousands in Israel Rally Against Netanyahu’s Government
item.description: It was one of the largest demonstrations against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government since the start of the war in October.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members and supporters of Israeli hostages held by Hamas at a protest outside the Kirya military headquarters in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: Can We Engineer Our Way Out of the Climate Crisis?
item.description: Blocking solar rays. Sucking carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Ideas that sound like science fiction are now starting to become reality, raising concerns about safety.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:credit: Francesca Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mammoth, a giant machine in Iceland that will pull planet-warming carbon dioxide out of the air.

item.title: Istanbul Mayor Headed for Re-election, in Blow to Erdogan’s Party
item.description: The opposition chalked up gains against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s ruling party in local elections across Turkey amid voter anger about the economy.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
item.media:description: Supporters of Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu in Istanbul on Sunday.

item.title: Police Raid Peruvian President’s Home, Looking for Rolex Watches
item.description: Dina Boluarte, who has been seen wearing luxury watches and a $50,000 bracelet, is under investigation for breaking the country’s unlawful enrichment and asset disclosure laws.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj
item.media:description: President Dina Boluarte of Peru speaking in San Francisco in November. She has declined to explain the origin of Rolexes she has been seen wearing.

item.title: Second Boat Carrying Aid to Gaza Departs Cyprus
item.description: World Central Kitchen, the charity founded by the chef José Andrés, said barges were carrying almost 400 tons of rice, pasta, flour, canned vegetables and proteins.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: A cargo ship transporting humanitarian aid bound for Gaza is escorted by Cyprus Port and Marine Police vessels, as seen from Larnaca, Cyprus, on Saturday.

item.title: What a New York Times Photographer Saw on a Gaza Airdrop
item.description: As humanitarian groups warn of a looming famine in northern Gaza, airdrops are playing a prominent role in efforts to deliver food and supplies, even if they are less efficient than delivery by truck.
item.dc:creator: Diego Ibarra Sanchez and Lars Dolder
item.media:description: The view from inside a C-130 military aircraft as the Jordanian air force dropped supplies over northern Gaza on Thursday.

item.title: In Praise of Tiny Triumphs
item.description: If full-on spring cleaning feels intimidating, why not focus instead on tasks that are far less ambitious but no less satisfying?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: ‘Punjabi Wave’ Music Hits the Juno Awards Stage
item.description: Karan Aujla, 27, became the first Punjabi artist to win an award at the Junos as the genre expands its fan base in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Darren Calabrese/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Karan Aujla accepting the Fan’s Choice Award at the Juno Awards on Sunday in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

item.title: How African Immigrants Have Revived a Remote Corner of Quebec
item.description: Hundreds of newcomers from Africa have filled a shortage of workers in Rouyn-Noranda, creating a new community in a remote mining town.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view across Lake Osisko in the northern Quebec mining town of Rouyn-Noranda.

item.title: Troop-Starved Ukrainian Brigades Turn to Marketing to Attract Recruits
item.description: Many units, which say the official conscription system is dysfunctional and unwieldy, have started their own recruitment campaigns to fill ranks depleted in the war with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut, Daria Mitiuk and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: An advertisement for the 67th Separate Mechanized Brigade, a part of Ukraine’s armed forces that includes the Da Vinci Wolves Battalion, in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Watch Live: Turkey’s Famous Stork
item.description: A 24-hour webcam allows stork lovers worldwide to watch Yaren, who returns to visit his human friend every year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yaren and Nazli in their nest in Eskikaraagac, Turkey.

item.title: What Is Happening With the Rohingya Refugees in Bangladesh?
item.description: Gunfights, kidnappings and homicides have become widespread in the refugee settlements in Bangladesh, as armed groups and criminal gangs have become more brazen.
item.dc:creator: Verena Hölzl
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Rohingya refugee camp, along the Naf River, near Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, in November.

item.title: A Stork, a Fisherman and Their Unlikely Bond Enchant Turkey
item.description: Thirteen years ago, a stork landed on a fisherman’s boat looking for food. He has come back every year since, drawing national attention.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard, Safak Timur and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adem Yilmaz in his fishing boat with his stork companion, Yaren.

item.title: Dispute in Israel Over Drafting Ultra-Orthodox Jews Threatens Netanyahu
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s cabinet is divided about whether ultra-Orthodox Jews should be required to join the Israeli army.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Johnatan Reiss
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli military officers and noncommissioned officers during a ceremony in January at the Shura base in central Israel.

item.title: King’s College Chapel, 438 Solar Panels and an Architectural Squabble in Cambridge
item.description: King’s College Chapel in Cambridge is one of several British landmarks that have installed solar panels, gratifying climate campaigners and ruffling feathers among some traditionalists.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: The view of the roof of the King’s College Chapel in Cambridge, England, with recently added solar panels.

item.title: What to Know About Jeffrey Donaldson, the Former DUP Leader
item.description: Mr. Donaldson resigned as party leader on Friday after being charged with non-recent sexual offenses.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: Jeffrey Donaldson in February 2023. His resignation on Friday upended politics in Northern Ireland.

item.title: Why Russia Is Protecting North Korea From Nuclear Monitors
item.description: The monitors have provided vivid evidence of how Russia is keeping Pyongyang brimming with fuel and other goods, presumably in return for weapons that Russia can use in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: A state media broadcast of a meeting between Kim Jong-un of North Korea and Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in September.

item.title: Airstrikes Kill Soldiers in Syria in Apparent Israeli Attack
item.description: Israel’s military did not immediately comment on the Syria strikes, but its defense minister said Israel would pursue Hezbollah, an Iran-backed militia, “every place it operates.”
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Aleppo, Syria, last year. Airstrikes hit near the site on Friday, killing 36 Syrian soldiers, seven Hezbollah fighters and a Syrian from a pro-Iranian militia, according to a group that tracks Syria’s civil war.

item.title: Czechs Accuse Men of ‘Russian Influence Operation’ in Europe
item.description: Amid news reports that European politicians received payments to promote Russian interests, the Czech government froze the assets of the men and a website, Voice of Europe.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Viktor Medvedchuk, a high-profile, pro-Russian Ukrainian politician, at a session of the Ukrainian Parliament in Kyiv in 2019. Arrested in 2022, he was handed over to Russia in a prisoner exchange.

item.title: How Climate Change Is Changing Heatwaves
item.description: Climate change is making heat waves linger for longer stretches of time, exacerbating the effects of extreme temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: Scorching temperatures this month in São Paulo, Brazil.

item.title: Israel Says It Is Committed to Getting Aid Into Gaza After ICJ Ruling
item.description: The country pointed to measures to deliver necessities by land, air and sea that aid groups say are not nearly sufficient to meet the need.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Humanitarian aid at a United Nations agency’s distribution center in the southern Gaza city of Rafah this month.

item.title: Manchester City-Arsenal and the Pointless Search for Scapegoats
item.description: As Arsenal and Manchester City meet, remember that titles are not always won head-to-head, and that being the second-best team in the world’s best league does not constitute failure.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Martin Odegaard and Arsenal lead the Premier League ahead of Sunday’s showdown with third-place Manchester City.

item.title: In Move to Protect Whales, Polynesian Indigenous Groups Give Them ‘Personhood’
item.description: Indigenous leaders of New Zealand, Tahiti and the Cook Islands signed a treaty that recognizes whales as legal persons. Conservationists hope it will lead to legal protections.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: Humpback whales like these two in French Polynesia are of particular importance to Indigenous groups in the region.

item.title: Teacher Secretly Sold His Students’ Art on Mugs and Shirts, Lawsuit Says
item.description: Parents of a dozen students at a school near Montreal accused an art teacher in a lawsuit of reproducing portraits from a class assignment and putting them on items that he offered for sale online.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb

item.title: A Loyal Israel Ally, Germany Shifts Tone as the Toll in Gaza Mounts
item.description: Supporting Israel is seen as a historic duty in Germany, but the worsening crisis has pushed German officials to ask whether that backing has gone too far.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Relatives of Israeli hostages taken by Hamas held pictures of Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, during his visit to Tel Aviv in October.

item.title: DUP Leader Jeffrey Donaldson Resigns After Sexual Offense Charges
item.description: Jeffrey Donaldson, the leader of the Democratic Unionist Party and a backer of strong ties with the U.K., has resigned after being arrested on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Jeffrey Donaldson, leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, arriving in January for a news conference at Hillsborough Castle, an official government residence in Northern Ireland.

item.title: Iran and Its Proxies: a Common Link in Mideast Conflicts
item.description: A monitoring group said that an Israeli strike on Syria hit multiple targets, including a weapons depot belonging to Hezbollah, the Iran-backed Lebanese militia. Here’s a closer look at Iran’s proxies in the region.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: Hezbollah fighters carrying out training exercises in southern Lebanon in May.

item.title: Radio Free Asia Leaves Hong Kong, Citing Security Law
item.description: Radio Free Asia, which ran a small operation in Hong Kong, said its staff was at risk because of the law’s sweeping definition of “external interference.”
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Journalists gathering at a court in Hong Kong to cover the trial of Jimmy Lai, the founder of Apple Daily, a pro-democracy newspaper.

item.title: Volcanic Eruptions Are Continuing in Iceland: Photos
item.description: Volcanic eruptions are continuing in the Reykjanes Peninsula in Iceland. Streets are empty and the Blue Lagoon resort remains closed.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Tony Cenicola
item.media:description: The plume from a volcanic eruption as viewed from Route 41 near the town of Kalfatjorn in western Iceland on Wednesday.

item.title: Girl Who Survived South Africa Bus Crash Is in Stable Condition
item.description: Forty-five church pilgrims from Botswana, along with the driver, were killed when the bus plunged off an overpass into a rocky ravine in South Africa. The only survivor was a little girl.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Yvonne Mooka
item.media:description: Gaolebale Siako, whose daughter was the sole survivor of a bus crash that killed worshipers on an Easter pilgrimage, was prayed over by Setonko Seboko in Molepolole, Botswana, on Friday.

item.title: After U.N. Cease-Fire Resolution, What’s Changed in Gaza War?
item.description: The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution on Monday that demands an immediate cease-fire in the Gaza Strip. Here’s a closer look at where the situation stands.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Palestinians amid debris on Wednesday after an overnight bombardment in Rafah.

item.title: Wanted in South Korea: Imperialism-Free Cherry Blossoms
item.description: Activists want to replace a variety of cherry tree associated with the Japanese colonial era with one they say is Korean. The science is messy.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Mike Ives, Hisako Ueno and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: Shin Joon Hwan, in a gray hat, examining cherry trees in southern Korea this month. He leads a group urging that a variety cultivated during the 20th-century Japanese occupation should be supplanted by one native to the peninsula.

item.title: ‘Gladiators,’ That ’90s Show, Is Back With Extra Muscle in Britain
item.description: A reboot of “Gladiators,” the musclebound 1990s staple, has attracted millions of viewers in Britain. Is appointment television back?
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Harsh Mongolian Winter Leaves Over 5 Million Animals Dead
item.description: Mass death caused by a weather event known in Mongolia as dzud has devastated herds, leaving thousands of families short of food.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon, Khaliun Bayartsogt and Somini Sengupta
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:description: A pile of sheep and goat carcasses in Bayanmunkh, in Mongolia’s Khentii Province. Nearly six million livestock have died in Mongolia this winter because of the dzud weather phenomenon.

item.title: From New England to Notre-Dame, a U.S. Carpenter Tends to a French Icon
item.description: Hank Silver, a timber framer based in Massachusetts, is one of a handful of foreigners who are helping to rebuild the Paris cathedral after the devastating fire in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hank Silver in Paris this month. The opportunity to work on a project like the renovation of Notre-Dame Cathedral comes “once in a millennium,” the carpenter said.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: One year since Russia jailed a U.S. reporter.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: The detention of Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter who has been behind bars in Russia for a year, has been extended for a fifth time.
